data.title: Ipswich Old South Cemetery
data.meta_description: The Old South Cemetery has approximately 1000 interments, and was used from 1756 till 1939. It sits between the South Green and the Ipswich River and is an easy walk from downtown. This comprehensive list of interments was created by the WPA.
data.text:
The Old South Cemetery measures at least 200’ wide and wider in some points, and extends 400’ to 500’ from the far edge of the South Green, to the bank overlooking the Ipswich River. The cemetery was first used in 1756. Regular burials here started about 1784, and it was used until about 1939, with some recent additions. The Works Progress Administration (WPA) surveyed this cemetery and the Old North Burying ground in 1935 and created about 900 records. The stones are quite old and beautiful, but many have been severely eroded, and there are also many tombs along one of the main avenues and many family plots. The front of the ground is bordered by an old iron fence. This cemetery is not far from the Ipswich Museum and the Whipple House, an extraordinary example of First Period architecture.

The following names, descriptions, and photos are from the FindaGrave site. Special thanks to Diane and Kate for sharing their photos. The map locations are from the 1935 WPA grid map. The last number refers to the number in the specific grid. For example, Caroline Adams below is grave # 4 in grid Grid 5D. Sizable family plots are noted. This index was created based on WPA records provided by Bruce Lang, the Ipswich Parks and Cemetery Dept., and the Findagrave site. It was updated in 2022 by Abbie Benfield and Gordon Harris.
